newsitem.title: USA: Fugitive surrenders after nationwide manhunt.
newsitem.headline: Fugitive surrenders after nationwide manhunt.

text.p: A 21-year-old man who had been the target of a nationwide manhunt has surrendered to police after telling authorities he feared for his life.
Police said Cheyne Kehoe used a church pastor as an intermediary and turned himself in Monday night at the county courthouse at Colville, Washington.

Kehoe and his brother, Chevie, 24, were the subjects of a manhunt after a videotape of the shootout, recorded by police cameras, was widely broadcast. The pair were stopped for driving with expired license plates.
Chevie Kehoe is still a fugitive.
The brothers face a 16-count indictment related to that incident in Ohio.
Stevens County Undersheriff Gilbert Geer said Kehoe was expected to face an extradition request by Ohio authorities.
The brothers are linked to the white-separatist Christian Identity movement and grew up in Colville.

Kehoe declined to answer reporters' questions when he surrendered at the courthouse but in a statement he read before he was taken inside he said he chose to turn himself in because he feared for his safety.

"The reason I acted in the manner I did was due to the actions taken against men like Randy Weaver, Gordon Kahl and Bob Mathews," he said. "When the government law enforcement agencies abused the individual rights of these men, I feared for my life."
Weaver, a white separatist, was involved in an FBI standoff in 1992 at his remote cabin in Ruby Ridge, Idaho. His son and wife were killed along with a federal marshal.
Kahl, a militant tax protester, got into a gun battle that killed two U.S. marshals in North Dakota in 1983. He was killed later that year in a shootout with police in Arkansas.
Mathews died in a 1984 fire that followed an exchange of gunfire with the FBI on Whidbey Island, Washington.
